    • Field Detail

      • EPSILON

        public static final java.lang.Character EPSILON
        Represents the empty string. This symbol is used to represent epsilon transitions.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Alphabet

        public Alphabet(java.util.List<java.lang.Character> symbols)
        Creates a new alphabet from the given list of symbols. We assume that the list does not contain duplicates.

        For example, the statement

        Alphabet abc = new Alphabet(new ArrayList<Character>(Arrays.asList('a', 'b', 'c')));

        creates a new alphabet object that represents the alphabet {a,b,c} with the lexicographical order given by a < b < c.

        Parameters:
        symbols - a list of character symbols

    • Method Detail

      • parse

        public static Alphabet parse(java.lang.String encoding)
        Creates a new alphabet from the string encoding of an alphabet.

        The format of the encoding is

         <char> <char> ...

        That is, the symbols are characters, separated by whitespace. The lexicographical order of the alphabet follows the order of the list. We assume that the list does not contain duplicates. For example, the statement

        Alphabet abc = Alphabet.parse('a b c');

        creates the alphabet 

        {a,b,c}
        with the lexicographical order given by 
        a < b < c.
        Parameters:
        encoding - a string encoding of an alphabet
        Returns:
        the alphabet object representing the encoded alphabet

      • prettyPrint

        public void prettyPrint(java.io.PrintStream out)
        Prints the alphabet in set notation.

        For example, the statements

        Alphabet abc = new Alphabet(new ArrayList<Character>(Arrays.asList('a', 'b', 'c'))); abc.prettyPrint(System.out);

        will print

        {a, b, c}

        on standard output.

        Parameters:
        out - the print stream on which to print this alphabet

      • encode

        public java.lang.String encode()
        Returns a string encoding of this alphabet.

        The encoding is identical to the format that Alphabet.parse accepts. In other words, encode() and parse() are inverses:

        forall anAlphabet : Alphabet | Alphabet.parse(anAlphabet.encode()).equals(anAlphabet)
        Returns:
        a string encoding of this alphabet

      • iterator

        public java.util.Iterator<java.lang.Character> iterator()
        Specified by:
        iterator in interface java.lang.Iterable<java.lang.Character>

      • contains

        public boolean contains(java.lang.Character symbol)
        Returns true if and only if symbol is a member of this alphabet.
        Parameters:
        symbol - a character
        Returns:
        true if and only if symbol is a member of this alphabet

      • first

        public java.lang.String first()
        Returns the first string in the lexicographical order of this alphabet (it's always the empty string).
        Returns:
        the empty string

      • next

        public java.lang.String next(java.lang.String string)
        Given a string from this alphabet, returns the next string in this alphabet's lexicographical order.

        For example, if alphabet is the alphabet {a,b,c} then

        alphabet.next("abc")

        returns the string "aca".

        Parameters:
        string - a string whose characters are members of this alphabet
        Returns:
        the next string in this alphabet's lexicographical order
